dt: {bc}one that is strongly masculine or has strong masculine appeal

shortdef: one that is strongly masculine or has strong masculine appeal —usually used in combination

dt: {bc}the 5th letter of the Hebrew alphabet {dx}see {dxt|Alphabet Table|alphabet|table}{/dx}

shortdef: the 5th letter of the Hebrew alphabet

dt.t: the {wi}where{/wi} and the how of the accident

dt: {bc}a place of central interest or activity
{bc}something (such as a topic or field of interest) of primary concern or importance
{bc}to the fullest extent of one's value or ability {dx}see also {dxt|for what it's worth|for what it's worth|}{/dx}

et: Middle English, "having monetary value, valuable, having status, deserving, highborn, efficacious, strong," going back to Old English {it}weorþ, wyrþ, worþ{/it} "having monetary value, valuable," going back to Germanic {it}*werþa-{/it} (whence also Old Frisian {it}werth{/it} "of value," Old Saxon {it}werth{/it} "of value, worthy, dear," Old High German {it}werd, wert{/it} "of value, valuable," Old Icelandic {it}verðr{/it} "of value, worthy," Gothic {it}wairþs{/it} "deserving"), of uncertain origin

The Middle English adjective continues in part Old English {it}wierðe, wyrðe{/it} "worthy, deserving," a ja-stem adjective from the same base. Welsh {it}gwerth{/it} "worth, value, price" (whence {it}gwerthu{/it} "to sell"), along with Middle Breton {it}guerz,{/it} is perhaps an early loan from Old English.

dt: used to say that one/someone is the person needed for a job

dt.t: If you need someone to help organize the files, {it}I'm/he's/she's your man{/it}!

shortdef: —used to say that one/someone is the person needed for a job

meta.id: know what one is talking about
stems: doesn't know what he's talking about
know what one is talking about

hwi.hw: know what one is talking about

dt: {bc}to be saying what is correct from actual knowledge or experience with something

dt.t: Take her advice. She {it}knows what she's talking about{/it}.
"He said the movie is boring." "Don't listen to him. He {phrase}doesn't know what he's talking about{/phrase}."

shortdef: to be saying what is correct from actual knowledge or experience with something

dt: used to say that what someone is saying is very surprising or hard to believe

dt.t: "The report is due by tomorrow." "{it}You're joking{/it}."

shortdef: —used to say that what someone is saying is very surprising or hard to believe

dt: used to say that one accepts a bet or challenge

dt.t: "I bet I can run faster than you can." "OK, {it}you're on{/it}."

shortdef: —used to say that one accepts a bet or challenge
